2. Line graphs & bar charts

  1. How many units were produced at 1111 hours?

    Answer: units
    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    STEP: Determine how many units were produced at 1111 hours
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Line graphs compare two variables. Each variable is plotted along an axis. Here we plotted time on the vertical axis against the number of units produced on the horizontal axis. Line graphs are good at showing specific values of data, so if we are given one variable, we can easily determine the other. Put your finger on 1111 hours and check which vertical value corresponds to this specific point. We can see that 33 units were produced at 1111 hours.

ID is: 2855 Seed is: 8866

Bar chart

A school started a recycling project. The bar chart below shows how many of each item they recycled last week:

  1. Which item did the school collect the most of?
  2. From the recycled items, which item did the school collect 5 kg5 kg of?
  3. Which item did the school collected the least of?
Answer:
  1. The most collected item is .
  2. The item for which 5 kg5 kg were collected is .
  3. The least collected item is .
2 attempts remaining
STEP: Read the relevant information from the chart
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

A bar graph is a chart that uses either horizontal or vertical bars to show comparisons among categories. The length of each rectangular bar is proportional to the values that it represents. One axis of the chart shows the specific categories being compared, in this case the different categories of recycled materials and the other axis represents a discrete value. Do you remember what discrete data are? Discrete data usually have numeric values and the items can be counted.

  • From the graph we can see the category that was collected the most was cans. This is represented by the highest bar, which represents the highest value 1515.
  • To find the answer to the second question we need to focus on the axis with the frequency of items, the vertical axis. Find the value 55 and follow a horizontal line across until you reach the bar that corresponds with that value. In this case, it is garden waste.
  • From the graph we can see the category that was collected the least was textiles. This is represented by the lowest bar, which represents the lowest value 33.
Submit your answer as: andand

3. Grouped frequency tables


ID is: 859 Seed is: 6900

Working with data sets: counting values

A group of 1515 students count the number of sweets they each have. Here are the data values they collected:

3;2;9;9;45;13;5;2;147;4;9;1;113;2;9;9;45;13;5;2;147;4;9;1;11

Count the number of students who have from 33 up to 55 sweets. In other words, how many students have sweets in the following range: 3≤number of sweets<63≤number of sweets<6?

TIP: It will be helpful to organise the data into a table.
Answer:

The number of students with sweets in that range is .

numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Start by arranging the numbers from smallest to largest. Then you can count how many of the values are in the range from 33 up to but not including 66.

STEP: Sort the data and count how many values are in the range from 33 up to but not including 66.
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

Firstly, we must sort the data values. This is not necessary, but it is the safest way to get the correct answer! In this case we want to group the values into intervals. A table is a good way to do this: we can sort the data into intervals which include the one we want.

The data values are:

3;2;9;9;45;13;5;2;147;4;9;1;113;2;9;9;45;13;5;2;147;4;9;1;11

We can list these in the intervals shown below. The interval we want is shaded.

Interval Data values Frequency
0≤x<30≤x<3 2;2;12;2;1 33
3≤x<63≤x<6 3;4;5;5;43;4;5;5;4 55
6≤x<96≤x<9 77 11
9≤x<129≤x<12 9;9;9;119;9;9;11 44
12≤x<1512≤x<15 13;1413;14 22

Note that the interval we want does not include data values equal to 66!

STEP: Visualise the data on a histogram
[−0 points ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We can see from the data list that the number of values in this range is 55.

NOTE:

We can represent the data on a histogram. The height of each bar is equal to the frequency values from the table above. The interval we are interested in for this question is shown in green.

The number of students with sweets in the range: 3≤number of sweets<63≤number of sweets<6 is 5.

4. Histograms & frequency polygons


ID is: 3750 Seed is: 5347

Frequency polygons: 2 in 1

The graph below shows two frequency polygons on a single plot. The data shown are how long it took runners in two different marathons to complete the race. Both marathons are the same distance (42.195 km42.195 km).

What is the largest frequency shown for Run Run Marathon?

Answer:

The largest frequency shown for Run Run Marathon is .

numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Start by figuring out which of the two frequency polygons shows the data for Run Run Marathon.

STEP: Determine which frequency polygon represents Run Run Marathon
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

We need to determine which frequency polygon represents Run Run Marathon. So the first thing to do is identify which of the two frequency polygons on the graph shows the data for Run Run Marathon. The legend tells us that Run Run Marathon is shown by the solid line.

STEP: Find the highest frequency
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Now we need to read off the highest frequency for this frequency polygon.

The point circled above shows where Run Run Marathon has the largest frequency. The arrow pointing to the left shows that the largest frequency is 8686.

NOTE: The point circled above does not mean that there are 8686 people with running times equal to 225225 minmin. Remember that frequency polygons show grouped data. So the point means there are 8686 people with running times in the interval centered on 225225. They do not all have to be equal to 225225 minmin.

The largest frequency shown for Run Run Marathon is 8686.

Frequency polygons: 2 in 1

The graph below shows two frequency polygons on a single plot. The data shown are the maximum daily temperatures in Johannesburg for the months of January and July.

What is the frequency for January when T=23T=23 °°C?

Answer:

The frequency for January when T=23T=23 °°C is .

numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Start by figuring out which of the two frequency polygons shows the data for January.

STEP: Determine which frequency polygon represents January
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

We need to determine which frequency polygon represents January. So the first thing to do is identify which of the two frequency polygons on the graph shows the data for January. The legend tells us that January is shown by the dashed line.

STEP: Find the correct frequency value
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Now we need to read off the correct frequency value for this frequency polygon.

The point circled above shows the point for January where TT is 2323. The frequency for that point is 88 as shown by the arrow pointing to the yy.-axis.

NOTE: The point circled above does not mean that there are 88 days with maximum temperatures equal to 2323 °°C. Remember that frequency polygons show grouped data. So the point means there are 88 days with maximum temperatures in the interval centered on 2323. They do not all have to be equal to 2323 °°C.

The frequency for January when T=23T=23 °°C is 88.

Matching graphs and types of data

From what kind or kinds of data would a bar graph be generated?

A categorical only
B one categorical and one quantitative
C varies according to situation
D quantitative only
Answer:

The correct type of data for a bar graph is choice .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Think about an example of a bar graph. What kinds of values go on the horizontal axis? What kinds of values go on the vertical axis?

STEP: Think about an example of a bar graph
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The question asks us to identify what type of data are used in a bar graph. Is it based on categorical data, quantitative data, or both? Here is some information about these data types:

  • Categorical data are organised into categories. For example, if you count the number of schools in each province, the provinces are categories. There are nine categories and each school fits into one of them. One useful fact about categorical data is that you can change the order of the categories. For the provinces, you could order them alphabetically. Or you could start with the province where you live.
  • Quantitative data are organised numerically (as numbers). For example, the heights of all the students in a class are quantitative data. Quantitative data typically follow some order, like smallest to largest.

Bar graphs are always based on categorical data. So a bar graph shows us values which are organised by category.

Here is an example of a bar graph. It shows people's favourite fruit out of five types of fruit. It is organised by the type of fruit.

The bar graph above shows data organised into five categories. Specifically, five types of fruit. Notice that these categories do not have any required order. We could move them into alphabetical order if we wanted to, or switch them to be the other way around. This is a characteristic of categorical data. The categories are similar, but they do not follow a specific order.

Here is the original table, with explanations for each choice.

A ✘ categorical only
False: A bar graph does not show categorical data only - the data on the y-axis is quantitative.
B ✔ one categorical and one quantitative
True: A bar graph shows categorical data on the x-axis and quantitative data on the y-axis.
C ✘ varies according to situation
False: A bar graph is used for categorical and quantitative data.
D ✘ quantitative only
False: A bar graph always includes categorical data.

The correct answer is choice one categorical and one quantitative.

Building a histogram

Imagine a histogram for the ratings many different people gave about a popular television show.

  1. Answer the following questions about the histogram:

    1. What quantity should go on the xx-axis of the histogram?
    2. What quantity should go on the yy-axis of the histogram?
    Answer:
    1. The quantity on the xx-axis should be: .
    2. The quantity on the yy-axis should be: .
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Reread the question. The yy-axis on a histogram always shows the number of data values (the frequency of values). The xx-axis always shows the values for the data themselves.

    STEP: Select the correct axis labels
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    This question is about making a histogram. Specifically, we need to figure out what quantities should go on the axes for a histogram about the situation in the question.

    The horizontal axis in a histogram must always show the possible values of the data. In this case the data values are the ratings people gave about the show. So the xx-axis must show those ratings.

    For any histogram the yy-axis always shows the number of data values in the various intervals. (This is often called the frequency.)

    For the histogram described in this question:

    1. The variable on the xx-axis should be: Rating.
    2. The variable on the yy-axis should be: Number of people.
    Submit your answer as: and

  2. Which of the pictures below shows the shape we should expect for the histogram? (Reminder: the data are about the ratings many different people gave about a popular television show.)

    A

    B

    C

    D
    Answer:

    The most reasonable shape to expect is choice .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Do you expect most of the ratings to be in the middle of the values, or will they mostly be smaller values? Or will they be spread out equally for all the values?

    STEP: Think about the way the data values will be spread out
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    To answer this question, we need to think about how the data values for the ratings will be spread out.

    The four images below show these basic situations:

    A

    Balanced shape: Most data values are in the centre with a balanced number of values on each side. This means values in the middle are more common than values on the left side or the right side. So a balanced distribution is more or less symmetric with the peak in the middle.

    B

    Flat shape: All data values are spread out equally. So values on the left side are just as common as values on the right side and in the middle. This typically represents something random. Note that a flat shape is not exactly flat - but it has no significant peaks.

    C

    Skewed right shape: The data values are clumped up on the left side with a "tail" to the right. This shows that for some reason the data values on the right side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are harder to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

    D

    Skewed left shape: The data values are clumped up on the right side with a "tail" to the left. This shows that for some reason the data values on the left side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are easier to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

    So which of these is the most reasonable to expect? The question states that the television show is popular. That means we should expect that most of the ratings are high, and not many ratings will be low. So the most likely shape for the real histogram is the skewed left shape.

    NOTE: It is possible that the histogram will have a different shape - we can't know for sure if we do not have the data values. So our answer is based on reasonable expectations about ratings for a popular show.

    Therefore the most reasonable shape to expect is choice D.

Locating a specific value in a histogram

The figure below shows a histogram which summarises 1818 data values. The data are spread out over four intervals.

If we consider the data values in order from smallest to largest, is the third data value in the interval 0≤x<50≤x<5 or not?

Answer:

The third data value in the interval 0≤x<50≤x<5.

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

You need to count your way through the data until you reach the third value. For example, there are 44 data values in the first interval, so the fifth data value is the first (smallest) number in the second interval.

STEP: Count your way through the data to locate the third value
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to determine if the third value in the data set is in the interval 0≤x<50≤x<5.

The data represented in the histogram are grouped in an ordered way. There are 44 values in the first interval, 0≤x<50≤x<5. We do not know exactly what those values are, but they have to be less than the values in the interval 5≤x<105≤x<10. For example, the first 1111 values in the data set could be:

0;0;1;3;5;5;7;8;8;8;9or0;2;3;4;7;7;7;8;9;9;90;0;1;3;5;5;7;8;8;8;9or0;2;3;4;7;7;7;8;9;9;9

We don't know the value of each number in the data. But the 44 values in the first interval must be less than the 77 values in the second interval. Similarly, the values in the second interval must all be less than the values in the third interval. Based on this fact, we can count our way through the data until we locate the third value.

In this case, we are looking for the third data value. It has to be in the first interval, because the first interval contains the first 44 data values. The question asks us if the third value is in the interval 0≤x<50≤x<5. This is the first interval, so the answer is yes.

The third data value is in the interval 0≤x<50≤x<5.

Histograms, frequency polygons, and bar graphs

  1. Which of these statements describes a difference between histograms and frequency polygons?

    A One is based on grouped data and the other is not.
    B One uses bars and one uses lines.
    C One is used for continuous data and one is for categorical data.
    D There is no difference.
    Answer:

    The correct statement is .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    You can read about frequency polygons here.

    STEP: Identify the difference between histograms and frequency polygons
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    This question is about the difference between histograms and frequency polygons. This difference is small: they are exactly the same except that histograms represent the data with bars while frequency polygons show the data as a line graph.

    Histogram

    Frequency polygon

    You can see that the frequency polygon matches the shape of the histogram.

    A ✘ One is based on grouped data and the other is not.
    False: Histograms and frequency polygons are both used for grouped data.
    B ✔ One uses bars and one uses lines.
    True: Histograms use bars while frequency polygons use lines.
    C ✘ One is used for continuous data and one is for categorical data.
    False: Histograms and frequency polygons are both used for continuous data.
    D ✘ There is no difference.
    False: There is a difference!

    The correct answer is choice B.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Which of these statements describes a difference between histograms and bar graphs?

    A One shows frequencies and the other does not.
    B One is used for continuous data and one is used for categorical data.
    C One uses bars and one uses lines.
    D There is no difference.
    Answer:

    The correct statement is .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Histograms and bar graphs look similar but they represent different kinds of data.

    STEP: Identify the difference between histograms and bar graphs
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Histograms and bar graphs look quite similar to each other, but they represent different types of data.

    • Histograms are used for continuous data. This means the data values can be any value in some range. In other words, the values are not necessarily separated from each other.
    • bar graphs represent categorical data. This means data that come in separate categories with nothing "between" the categories. For example, the categories might be different types of fruit. Each type of fruit is separate from other types: we cannot change a banana into a pineapple.

    Here is an example of a bar graph shown in two different ways. It shows people's favourite types of graphs. The type of graph is the category.

    Ordered by decreasing popularity

    Ordered alphabetically by category

    For a bar graph we can choose the order of the bars because the categories do not follow any particular order. And the bars do not touch because the categories are separate. For a histogram the bars must come in order. They should also touch each other because continuous data is ordered (from smallest to largest) and it does not have gaps.

    A ✘ One shows frequencies and the other does not.
    False: Histograms and bar graphs both show frequencies (because they count things).
    B ✔ One is used for continuous data and one is used for categorical data.
    True: Histograms show continuous data but bar graphs show categorical data.
    C ✘ One uses bars and one uses lines.
    False: Histograms and bar graphs both use bars.
    D ✘ There is no difference.
    False: There is a difference!

    The correct answer is choice B.

    Submit your answer as:

    C ✘ One is based on grouped data and the other is not.
    False: Histograms and frequency polygons are both used for grouped data.
    D ✘ There is no difference.
    False: There is a difference!

    The correct answer is choice B.

  2. Which of these statements describes a difference between histograms and bar graphs?

    A One uses bars and one uses lines.
    B One is used for continuous data and one is used for categorical data.
    C One shows frequencies and the other does not.
    D There is no difference.
    Answer:

    The correct statement is .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Histograms and bar graphs look similar but they represent different kinds of data.

    STEP: Identify the difference between histograms and bar graphs
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Histograms and bar graphs look quite similar to each other, but they represent different types of data.

    • Histograms are used for continuous data. This means the data values can be any value in some range. In other words, the values are not necessarily separated from each other.
    • bar graphs represent categorical data. This means data that come in separate categories with nothing "between" the categories. For example, the categories might be different types of fruit. Each type of fruit is separate from other types: we cannot change a banana into a pineapple.

    Here is an example of a bar graph shown in two different ways. It shows people's favourite types of graphs. The type of graph is the category.

    Ordered by decreasing popularity

    Ordered alphabetically by category

    For a bar graph we can choose the order of the bars because the categories do not follow any particular order. And the bars do not touch because the categories are separate. For a histogram the bars must come in order. They should also touch each other because continuous data is ordered (from smallest to largest) and it does not have gaps.

    A ✘ One uses bars and one uses lines.
    False: Histograms and bar graphs both use bars.
    B ✔ One is used for continuous data and one is used for categorical data.
    True: Histograms show continuous data but bar graphs show categorical data.
    C ✘ One shows frequencies and the other does not.
    False: Histograms and bar graphs both show frequencies (because they count things).
    D ✘ There is no difference.
    False: There is a difference!

    The correct answer is choice B.

Common histogram errors

The histogram below shows the amount of time 7070 different students spent doing homework one evening after school. But there is a problem: there is an error in the histogram.

What is the problem with this histogram? Select your answer from the choices below.

A The intervals should have equal widths
B The axis labels are swapped
C The y-axis values are incorrect
D There are not enough intervals
Answer:

The problem is choice .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Compare the histogram to what you expect to see. What is different? What does not agree with the information given in the question?

STEP: Compare the given histogram to what you expect to see
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to identify the problem with the histogram given above. To do this we need to compare the histogram to what we expect to see.

The problem here is that the second interval is not the same width as the other intervals. All intervals on a histogram should be the same width so that we can make useful comparisons between the number of data values in each interval. If one interval is wider than another, we cannot interpret the height of that bar effectively.

The problem with the histogram is that the intervals should have equal widths, which is choice A.

  2. In statistics, correlation refers to a relationship between two quantities. This relationship might be very strong, very weak, or somewhere in between. Or it might not exist at all. There are three types of relationships:

    • Positive correlation: the quantities increase together and decrease together. This is like a linear graph with a positive gradient.
    • Negative correlation: when one of the quantities increases the other quantity decreases and vice versa. This is like a linear graph with a negative gradient.
    • Weak or no correlation: the quantities do not change in a tightly related way. For example, when one of the quantities increases the other quantity might increase and then decrease and then increase again.

    Based on the graph in Question 1, what type of correlation is there, if any, between number of units and average rental cost?

    Answer:

    The bar graph and the line graph show .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Do number of units and average rental cost increase together? If so, they have a positive correlation. If they move in opposite directions they have a negative correlation.

    STEP: Compare the patterns on the bar graph and the line graph
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    This question is about how number of units and average rental cost are related to each other. The question describes what correlation means. Here is another way to describe it:

    • If two quantities move together (increasing together and decreasing together) they have a positive correlation.
    • If two quantities move in opposite directions (one increasing when the other decreases) they have a negative correlation.
    • If two quantities move independently of each other then there is little or no correlation between them.

    The graph here shows a negative correlation. As the number of units increases the average cost decreases. They move in opposite directions. The reason is not obvious. Perhaps the buildings with fewer units have larger and more expensive flats and the buildings with lots of units have smaller units.

    NOTE: You will learn how to calculate the correlation between two quantities in Grade 12.

    Number of units and average rental cost have a negative correlation.

ID is: 3756 Seed is: 1309

Definition: frequency polygons

The statement below is about frequency polygons. Complete the statement by choosing the best options from the lists.

Answer:

A frequency polygon is a for grouped data. You can make a frequency polygon by joining all the of the top of the bars of a histogram.

2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

You can read about frequency polygons here.

STEP: Complete the statement about frequency polygons
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

A frequency polygon is a line graph which shows the same information as a histogram. It is easy to draw a frequency polygon onto a histogram. We put a point at the top of each bar in the middle of the bar (at the midpoint of the interval).

A frequency polygon is the same as a histogram but it looks different. Instead of bars, the frequency polygon is made of lines.

Therefore the correct statement is:

A frequency polygon is a line graph for grouped data. You can make a frequency polygon by joining all the midpoints of the top of the bars of a histogram.

Pairing data sets and histograms

A group of students count the number of marbles they each have. This is a histogram describing the data they collected:

A cat jumps onto the table and knocks their papers off of the table. Their notes with all of the data land on the floor, mixed up! Help them find which of the following data sets match the above histogram:

Data Set A

7;4;4;5;1411;9;8;3;125;7;9;14;117;4;4;5;1411;9;8;3;125;7;9;14;11

Data Set B

1;2;8;5;29;3;8;1;91;2;8;5;29;3;8;1;9

Data Set C

2;3;6;3;89;6;8;5;22;3;6;3;89;6;8;5;2
Answer:

The data set that matches the histogram is: .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Start by arranging the data for one of the groups in order. Then compare the data values to the histogram.

STEP: Compare the data sets to the histrogram
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

To answer this question we must group the three data sets in the same intervals we see in the histogram. We want to find out which data set has the same frequencies as the histogram.

The histogram shows intervals which start at zero and are each 22 wide. We can list the data in Data Set A these intervals to see if the frequencies match the histogram. Using mm to represent the number of marbles:

Intervals Values Frequency
0≤m<20≤m<2 NoneNone 00
2≤m<42≤m<4 33 11
4≤m<64≤m<6 4;4;5;54;4;5;5 44
6≤m<86≤m<8 7;77;7 22
8≤m<108≤m<10 9;8;99;8;9 33
Not in an interval 14;11;12;14;1114;11;12;14;11 55

Do these frequency values match the histogram? No, they do not. So Set A is not the correct answer. That means we need to make a table like this one above for Set B to see if it agrees with the histogram. If it is not correct, then Set C must be the correct answer.

The correct answer is: Data Set B

Frequency polygons

Frequency polygons show grouped data with a line graph. The graph below contains two frequency polygons which show the maximum daily temperatures in Johannesburg for the months of January and July. Use the graph to answer the two questions which follow.

Answer:
  1. How many more days were there in the interval represented by 17°C17°C for January than for July? .
  2. Are temperatures higher in January or July? .
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Start by finding the frequency values for the interval centred on 17°C17°C.

STEP: Find the frequencies for the correct interval and subtract
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

The first question asks us to find the difference in maximum temperature for the two months in the interval centred on 17°C17°C.

To do that, we need to subtract the frequencies for that interval.

The frequencies are 55 for January and 44 for July. This means that 55 days in January had a maximum temperature around 17°C17°C, while in July, 44 days had a maximum temperature around 17°C17°C.

To find the difference in maximum temperature we subtract these numbers.

5−4=15−4=1

The difference in maximum temperature in the specified interval is 11.

STEP: Identify which month is correct (if either)
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

For the second question we need to identify are temperatures higher in january or july. To answer this question we must focus on the horizontal axis. Moving to the right along the graph corresponds to increasing maximum temperature. If a frequency polygon falls mostly on the right side then it shows relatively large maximum temperature. But if a frequency polygon mostly falls on the left side, it indicates most of the maximum temperature are relatively small.

So this question comes down to the shape of the two frequency polygons. Which of the frequency polygons (if either) has a peak on the right?

The answer must be January, because it has a peak to the right while July has a peak to the left.

The month with the higher maximum temperature is January.

Histogram shapes

Suppose we have a data set for the amount of food 3737 people ate for dinner. Which of the pictures below shows the shape we should expect for the histogram?

A

B

C

D
Answer:

The most reasonable shape to expect is choice .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Do you expect most of the data values to be in the middle of the values, or will they mostly be smaller values? Or will they be spread out equally for all the values?

STEP: Think about the way the data values will be spread out
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

To answer this question, we need to think about how the data values for the amount of food people ate will be spread out.

The images in the question show these four basic situations:

A

Balanced shape: Most data values are in the centre with a balanced number of values on each side. This means values in the middle are more common than values on the left side or the right side. So a balanced distribution is more or less symmetric with the peak in the middle.

B

Flat shape: All data values are spread out equally. So values on the left side are just as common as values on the right side and in the middle. This typically represents something random. Note that a flat shape is not exactly flat - but it has no significant peaks.

C

Skewed right shape: The data values are clumped up on the left side with a "tail" to the right. This shows that for some reason the data values on the right side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are harder to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

D

Skewed left shape: The data values are clumped up on the right side with a "tail" to the left. This shows that for some reason the data values on the left side are less common. This would happen if larger values (on the right side) are easier to achieve than smaller values (on the left side).

So which of these is the most reasonable to expect for the amount of food people ate?

Most people eat similiar amounts. Some will eat less and some will eat more. But most people dish about the same amount onto their plates, most of the time. So we should expect a balanced shape for this data set.

NOTE: It is possible that the histogram will have a different shape - we can't know for sure if we do not have the data values. So our answer is based on reasonable expectations about the situation described in the question.

The most reasonable shape to expect is choice A.

ID is: 3725 Seed is: 1239

Histograms vs bar graphs

  1. What is the difference between a histogram and a bar graph? Or are they the same?

    Pick your answer from the choices below.

    A Histograms show categorical data while bar graphs show continuous quantitative data.
    B Histograms show data with lines while bar graphs show data with bars.
    C Histograms show continuous quantitative data while bar graphs show categorical data.
    D There is no difference between a histogram and a bar graph.
    Answer:

    The correct description of the difference is option .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Histograms are used for data which is grouped into intervals. Bar graphs show data which is organised into categories.

    STEP: Determine what types of data are appropriate for histograms and bar graphs
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Histograms and bar graphs are easy to confuse because they look like each other. But they are not the same! The difference is the type of data that they show.

    • Histogram A histogram uses bars to show continuous data. The data must be grouped into intervals. The bars touch each other because the data are continuous. A histogram shows the same information as a frequency polygon, but with bars instead of a line.
    • Bar graph A bar graph uses bars to show categorical data. That means data which are organised into categories. For example, types of cars or different provinces are categories. Such data cannot be grouped in intervals because the categories are separate from each other. The bars often do not touch each other because the data are not continuous.

    One key difference between histograms and bar graphs is the order of the values on the horizontal axis. The values for a histogram must be in order, because the data are continuous. But for bar graphs the order of the values can change. They can change because the categories themselves do not have a specific order.

    TIP: To decide if data belong in a histogram or a bar graph, ask yourself if the order of the data groups can be shifted or not. If the order cannot be shifted, you are dealing with a histogram situation.

    The difference between histograms and bar graphs is that histograms show continuous quantitative data while bar graphs show categorical data. The correct choice is C.

Histograms vs bar graphs

  1. What is the difference between a histogram and a bar graph? Or are they the same?

    Pick your answer from the choices below.

    A Histograms show data with lines while bar graphs show data with bars.
    B Histograms show continuous quantitative data while bar graphs show categorical data.
    C Histograms show categorical data while bar graphs show continuous quantitative data.
    D There is no difference between a histogram and a bar graph.
    Answer:

    The correct description of the difference is option .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Histograms are used for data which is grouped into intervals. Bar graphs show data which is organised into categories.

    STEP: Determine what types of data are appropriate for histograms and bar graphs
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Histograms and bar graphs are easy to confuse because they look like each other. But they are not the same! The difference is the type of data that they show.

    • Histogram A histogram uses bars to show continuous data. The data must be grouped into intervals. The bars touch each other because the data are continuous. A histogram shows the same information as a frequency polygon, but with bars instead of a line.
    • Bar graph A bar graph uses bars to show categorical data. That means data which are organised into categories. For example, types of cars or different provinces are categories. Such data cannot be grouped in intervals because the categories are separate from each other. The bars often do not touch each other because the data are not continuous.

    One key difference between histograms and bar graphs is the order of the values on the horizontal axis. The values for a histogram must be in order, because the data are continuous. But for bar graphs the order of the values can change. They can change because the categories themselves do not have a specific order.

    TIP: To decide if data belong in a histogram or a bar graph, ask yourself if the order of the data groups can be shifted or not. If the order cannot be shifted, you are dealing with a histogram situation.

    The difference between histograms and bar graphs is that histograms show continuous quantitative data while bar graphs show categorical data. The correct choice is B.

    Submit your answer as:

Histograms & frequency polygons

Suppose someone collects data about the number of soccer teams in the PSL (Premier Soccer League) which have scored a certain number of goals.

  1. What quantity belongs on the horizontal axis if we graph this data set?
  2. Will this data set be well represented by a frequency polygon?
Answer:
  1. The quantity on the horizontal axis will be .
  2. A frequency polygon for this data set.
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Remember that frequency polygons are used for showing continuous data split into a number of different intervals. If the data are not continuous, or if they cannot be broken into at least three intervals, a frequency polygon is not a good choice.

STEP: Determine if the data have the properties needed for a frequency polygon
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to determine what quantity should go on the horizontal axis if we make a graph for the data described in the question. And we must decide if the data mentioned in the question can be represented in a frequency polygon.

These questions are related: the first question is about how the data are organised. And once we know how they are organised we will know the answer to the second question. This is because a frequency polygon requires two things:

  • The data are continuous (not categorical).
  • The data can be broken into at least 33 intervals.

To determine if the data are continuous or categorical we need to determine how the data are organised. And that comes from the quantity on the horizontal axis. If that quantity is a list of categories, the data are categorical. But if that quantity is continuous, the data are continuous.

The data in this case are about how many teams have scored different numbers of goals. These data are organised by the number of goals which could be as low as zero but as high as (perhaps) 4040 or 5050. So the data are continuous and we can divide the data set into intervals. So a frequency polygon is a good choice for this data set.

NOTE: Any data set which is suitable for a frequency polygon is also suitable for a histogram.

The correct answers are:

  1. The quantity on the horizontal axis should be number of goals.
  2. A frequency polygon is appropriate for this data set.

Matching: types of graphs

Which one of the three graphs below shows a bar graph?

A

B

C
Answer:

The bar graph is option .

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Think about an example of a bar graph. What kinds of values go on the horizontal axis? What kinds of values go on the vertical axis?

STEP: Identify the bar graph
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to identify which of the graphs shown is a bar graph.

The three graphs shown are a frequency polygon, a histogram, and a bar graph.

A

Frequency polygon: A frequency polygon is a line graph. It shows continuous data which has been grouped into intervals. A frequency polygon shows the same information as a histogram, but with lines instead of bars.

B

Histogram: A histogram uses bars to show continuous data. The data must be grouped into intervals. The bars touch each other because the data are continuous. A histogram shows the same information as a frequency polygon, but with bars instead of lines.

C

Bar graph: A bar graph uses bars to show categorical data. The means data which come in categories, like types of cars or different provinces. Categorical data are not grouped in intervals. The bars often do not touch each other because the data are not continuous.

NOTE: Bar graphs and histograms look similar and are easy to confuse. One key difference is that the order of the bars in a bar graph can be moved around because the data are not continuous. But the bars in a histogram must be in order (i.e. from smaller numbers to larger).

We are looking for the bar graph, which is option C.

  1. The minimum is .
  2. The maximum is .

numeric

[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

STEP: Determine the minimum and maximum number of values which can be less than or equal to 00
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

When dealing with grouped data, it is important to be able to know how many data values there are above or below a given value on the xx-axis. In this question we need to figure out the minimum and maximum number of teams for which the goal total was less than or equal to 0 goals0 goals.

The boundary is the lower boundary of the first interval. We need to count up the number of values which are less than 00 or which are equal to 00. None of the values can be less than 00 (because then they would not belong in the first interval). But it is possible that some of them are equal to 00. All we know is that the number of values less than or equal to 00 is anywhere from zero up to 44.

The minimum number of values is zero and the maximum is 44.

We can read the answer directly from the histogram. The height of each bar shows the number of students in that interval. We want to know the number of students in the interval from 88 up to 1212. This is the third interval, and the bar is shaded below.

The number at the top of each bar shows the bar's frequency. That means the number of students who have a number of playing cards in the interval for that bar.

The correct answer is: 44.

5. Pie charts


ID is: 2870 Seed is: 9961

Calculating degrees for a sector in a pie chart

Answer the two questions below about this pie chart.

  1. Calculate the missing value represented by xx.
  2. How many degrees is sector xx? (Round your answer to two decimal places)
Answer:
  2. °°
one-of
type(fraction.unsimplified)
numeric
2 attempts remaining
STEP: Find the value of xx
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

Remember the “pie” represents some kind of whole, which is made up of the slices. Add up all the slices and we get the complete pie. Here the slices known as sectors are divided into values represented as fractions. All the fractions have the same denominator; thus, to get whole "pie", we need to end up with a value like this: 23232323. This evaluates to 1, the whole pie. So xx will be 823823.

STEP: Find the size of sector xx
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

To find the number of degrees a sector should be in a pie chart you can follow these steps:

  • Find the total amount used in the data in this case it was 23
  • What ratio of this total is represented by this sector? Here it was 823823
  • Multiply your ratio with 360 °° (Remember a full revolution = 360 °°)
Sector°=823×360°=125,22°Sector°=823×360°=125,22°

So xx has a fraction value of 823823, which is the same as 125,22°°.

Pie charts

The following statistics are related to the amount of drinking water consumed in different districts in South Africa. (These values are made up values and not a real representation of this event).

  1. Which district uses the most water?
  2. Which district uses the least water?
  3. What is the range of drinking water consumption between the districts?
Answer:
  1. The district which uses the most water is
  2. The district which uses the least water is
  3. The range is %%
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

For Questions 1 and 2, you can read the answers off of the pie chart. For Question 3 you must do one calculation to get the answer.

STEP: Read off the information you need from the pie chart
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

For these answers we just need to read the correct answer from the pie chart. The legend corresponds with the sectors by colour. So when we are looking for the highest value, we need to find the highest percentage on the pie chart. Then we check in the legend which name corresponds with the colour of that sector.

The district with the greatest water consumption is Chris Hani because it has the largest percentage (35%35%). And the district with the lowest water consumption is OR Tambo because it has the smallest percentage (13%13%).

STEP: Use the maximum and minimum values to find the range
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

For Question 3 we need to calculate the range. Remember the range is calculated by taking the highest value from the data and subtracting the lowest value from that.

Range=Highest value - Lowest value=35−13=22%Range=Highest value - Lowest value=35−13=22%

Therefore:

  1. The district which uses the most water is Chris Hani.
  2. The district which uses the least water is OR Tambo.
  3. The range is 2222%%.
